Its about the sample set you are viewing: 

If you don't see all of the money-losing emails or the tweets that are wrong, you are led to a false conclusion.

This is how survivorship bias works...

Send out 40,000 emails, half say BUY STOCKS NOW, the other half says SELL STOCKS NOW. 

Repeat every other month (but only with the winning half). 

After a year, you have over 1000 people who believe you are Nostradamus and will send you lots of money. https://t.co/N2KvLDQFvc

The problem with guessing: It is exceedingly difficult to do, very few do it well, and there are deep penalties for getting it wrong.

Even worse, investors who mistime this often end up selling out at the worst times; over 30% never return to equity markets again.

Some believe that the low rate era is over, and rates will never return to zero; others believe things will peak and reverse (let's ignore the hyper-inflationistas for now).

You can guess what the outcome might be, or ride it out, regardless of how painful it might be.

Eventually, the snafus and inventory shortfall will get corrected, but it doesn't appear to be either quick or easy. 

The key question is what happens afterwards? Where do rates go when the imbalance between supply and demand returns to quasi-normal.

The good news is all of those fiscal dollars allowed people to survive the lockdowns; the bad news is it goosed demand for goods and houses, both of which were in short supply with fragile supply chains. 

That fiscal stimulus is why we had such a massive inflation spike.

The pandemic ironically led to the opposite situation: At $2T + 10% of GDP, the first CARES Act (2020) was the largest fiscal stimulus in US history; The 2nd CARES Act (also 2020) added another trillion dollars; the 3rd CARES Act (2021) was yet another $1T
The emphasis on monetary policy over fiscal stimulus ended up causing all manner of dislocations: It overweighted financial assets, it devalued labor, and it made wealth inequality worse.

It was also one of several legs that helped to drive prices higher in equity markets. 

Now that rates are higher and may go up even more, markets are having a hard time figuring out the full impact of no-longer-free capital.

Since the mid- to late-1990s, this monetary largesse made anything purchased with credit cheaper: Houses, cars, vendor-financed equipment, etc.

This obviously helped an already robust economy grow even faster...

Ever since Alan Greenspan was Fed Chair, the world has become accustomed to ultra-low rates, (nearly) free capital, and excess liquidity.  

Returning to a more normal monetary regime is a difficult and painful transition.

"The actual amount of annual debt payments that would be reduced now, during this present inflationary episode, will probably run to tens of billions of dollars, not hundreds of billions."

Many of these debtors were not going to make these payments anyway as they are broke.

The error is compounded by assuming students will "take their forgiven debt + go on a spending spree, a splurge of such magnitude that they will somehow find someone in the private sector willing to lend them the same amount at low-interest rates."

That's not going to happen...

Calculating the cost for ‚Äúthe present discounted value of foregone payments‚Äù ignores these are loans paid back over 10-20 years. 

Stiglitz argues that by misunderstanding this, inflation hawks overstate the impact of the program

Stiglitz: "Whatever your view of student-debt cancellation, the inflation argument is a red herring and should not influence policy."

Fiscal Stimulus = Employment + Consumer Spending + Inflation

Monetary Stimulus  = Increased Credit + Cheap Capital + Rising Asset Prices + More Risk Taking + Greater Wealth Inequality

The reaction to the 2007-09 GFC was an excessive monetary response but a fiscal response orders of magnitude too small. 

Despite the massive Fed response of ZIRP / QE for the next decade, inflation remained nascent.

Reminder: The parties most responsible for Inflation are Covid-19 & Congress.

For me, it looks something like  this: About half of my scenarios (percentage-wise) are pretty good, and half are not so good. 

6/ https://t.co/GVWY7K7DEc

The probabilities are we end up somewhere in the range between the extreme outliers. 

I came up with 5 probable outcomes: 

1. Strong positive
2. Weak positive
3. Neutral 
4. Weak negative
5. Strong negative. 

Assign a probability to each -- what does that look like? 

5/

Imagine a scenario where nearly everything goes right -- what does that look like in terms of the economy and markets?

Now imagine one where nearly everything goes wrong, what are the ramifications?

4/

Consider the 5 biggest challenges facing the US & world today: 

1. Inflation 
2. War 
3. Recession 
4. Covid 
5. Markets / Volatility

What do your (reasonably) best-case + worst-case scenarios look like?

3/

@sskyrius And Stradivari violins are priceless.

Both are a function of rare hardwoods (+ chemicals used) -- but not the compounding of incremental technological advances over time

Changes compound, just as surely as dollars do. A mathematical sleight of hand that also occurs at a near geologic pace. But miraculous all of these changes are. This is how the world changes.

‚ÄúGradually, then suddenly.‚Äù Perhaps that should be the mantra of investors.

Same with investing. You may not realize you live in  golden age of investing: 

-Trades are free
-Buy entire market @ 4 bps. 
-Own any asset in world
-All from your phone

All of these little changes over 50 years are hardly noticeable. But they add up + change the world.

The C2 Corvette is a gorgeous + sexy 1960s car. It has drum brakes, manual steering, heavy clutch, lap belts, no passenger-side mirror!

It looks great + sounds fantastic, but driving a 1967 anything makes you realize just how far the technology has advanced in 50+ years.
A favorite optical illusion -- the wildest part? Its only 2 seconds long https://t.co/5w7Gk2CNBm

This is how the world changes, slowly, but it adds up. In Ernest Hemingway‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Sun Also Rises,‚Äù a character is asked how he went bankrupt: ‚ÄúGradually, then suddenly.‚Äù 

Name a better 3-word phrase that explains nearly everything. Maybe Willam Goldman‚Äôs ‚ÄúNobody knows anything.‚Äù

We take incremental changes for granted. This is how the world usually progresses, in small evolutionary steps with the occasional massive leap.

@koenfucius It's a simple equation: Distance = Speed X Time

Even if both are standing + "sacrificing distance" we cannot omit Time, which works to the benefit of the 5 mph escalator over the 0 mph stairs.

@koenfucius 2 people: Stairs (A) + Escalator (B)

A stands for 2 minutes: 0 progress
B stands for 2 minutes: Gets to next floor, progresses. 

There is no debate here so long as you avoid the academic error of pretending the escalator is not working or stops and starts.

What purpose does your capital serve?

If you can answer that question well, you find yourself enjoying a life that is more satisfying and fulfilling.

/end

Purposeful capital is about more than just getting "more" - it is money that is being used for a worthwhile reason. 

5/

Without a purpose, money is merely an entry in an accounting ledger. But capital tied to a useful purpose has magical powers.

Think of all the new technology, businesses and jobs  Venture has created; Consider how much good charity/philanthropy has done in the world...

4/

Break it into halves:
1. Defining the ambitions of capital - towards what purpose it is being used. 
2. Once you figure that out, how should you then manage that fortune towards your goals?

Failing to consider these issues may result in dissatisfaction, unhappiness + losses.

3/

The spectacular rise + fall Bill Hwang and Archegos Capital Management were a great leaping off point to consider the philosophical purposes of money, as well as it's opposite: Purposeless Capital.

2/

About a year ago, we discussed an intriguing issue: What is the purpose of money?

@FiSurgi 4 drivers:

1. Investment Philosophy: What is a stock worth? Value, GARP, EBITDA, DFCF, etc. 

2. Sentiment: How much enthusiasm is there for equities?

3. Wealth: How liquid are buyers + how much available capital is around?

4. Supply: How much stock is available vs Demand?
